claim: Figure 1 shows a 2D mesh example and its corresponding contour tree.
title: Fig. 1.
caption: A 2D mesh example and its corresponding contour tree. The 2D mesh is segmented into subregions based on the contour tree

claim: The framework of topology-aware illumination design proposed in this paper is illustrated in Fig. 2.
title: Fig. 2.
caption: Framework of topology-aware illumination design

claim: From the comparison, we see that all renderings (Fig. 3d–f) from approaches presented in this paper show internal structures more clearly (e.g. structures pointed by A) than other approaches by emphasising internal structures from the illumination perspective.
title: Fig. 3.
caption: Volume rendering of fuel data set with various illumination approaches: a Conventional illumination, b Constant illumination, c Importance illumination (persistence, w = 0.71), d Distance illumination (persistence, w = 0.71), e Saliency illumination (persistence, w = 0.71), f Perceptual illumination

claim: Structures in Fig. 3f show larger illumination differences among structures than renderings in other figures.
title: Fig. 3.
caption: Volume rendering of fuel data set with various illumination approaches: a Conventional illumination, b Constant illumination, c Importance illumination (persistence, w = 0.71), d Distance illumination (persistence, w = 0.71), e Saliency illumination (persistence, w = 0.71), f Perceptual illumination

claim: Figure 4 shows the comparison of renderings using various approaches.
title: Fig. 4.
caption: Volume rendering of neghip data set with various illumination approaches: a Conventional illumination, b Constant illumination, c Importance illumination (persistence, w = 0.78), d Distance illumination (persistence, w = 0.57), e Saliency illumination (persistence, w = 0.67), f Perceptual illumination

claim: Similar conclusions as in Fig. 3 were got in this comparison.
title: Fig. 3.
caption: Volume rendering of fuel data set with various illumination approaches: a Conventional illumination, b Constant illumination, c Importance illumination (persistence, w = 0.71), d Distance illumination (persistence, w = 0.71), e Saliency illumination (persistence, w = 0.71), f Perceptual illumination

claim: More obviously, objects rendered in Fig. 4f show higher perceptual contrast in illuminations than other figures, which allows users more easily detect structural differences and structural details.
title: Fig. 4.
caption: Volume rendering of neghip data set with various illumination approaches: a Conventional illumination, b Constant illumination, c Importance illumination (persistence, w = 0.78), d Distance illumination (persistence, w = 0.57), e Saliency illumination (persistence, w = 0.67), f Perceptual illumination

claim: From the comparison in Fig. 5, we see that topological illumination shows more structural details such as skin surface and brain shapes (Fig. 5b to Fig. 5d) despite conventional illumination also depicting tumours clearly.
title: Fig. 5.
caption: Volume rendering of tumor head data set with various illumination approaches: a Conventional illumination, b Importance illumination (volume, w = 0.28), c Distance illumination (volume, w = 0.5), d Perceptual illumination

claim: It is found that perceptual illumination as shown in Fig.5d creates higher and balanced perceptual contrast between objects than other illumination methods.
title: Fig. 5.
caption: Volume rendering of tumor head data set with various illumination approaches: a Conventional illumination, b Importance illumination (volume, w = 0.28), c Distance illumination (volume, w = 0.5), d Perceptual illumination

claim: For example, compared with conventional illumination, importance illumination emphasises structures which have high volume (thumb bones in Fig. 6b), and high persistence (kneecap in Fig. 7b).
title: Fig. 6.
caption: Volume rendering of foot data set with various illumination approaches: a Conventional illumination, b Importance illumination (volume, w = 0.65), c Distance illumination (volume, w = 0.65), d Perceptual illumination

claim: For example, compared with conventional illumination, importance illumination emphasises structures which have high volume (thumb bones in Fig. 6b), and high persistence (kneecap in Fig. 7b).
title: Fig. 7.
caption: Volume rendering of CT-Knee data set with various illumination approaches: a Conventional illumination, b Importance illumination (persistence, w = 0.76), c Distance illumination (persistence, w = 0.76), d Perceptual illumination

claim: Figure 8 shows the rendering results of biological cell data set (test data from Vaa3D [1]) with different illumination approaches.
title: Fig. 8.
caption: Volume rendering of Cell data set with various illumination approaches: a Conventional illumination, b Importance illumination (volume, w = 0.74), c Distance illumination (volume, w = 0.74), d Perceptual illumination

claim: For example, compared with conventional illumination in Fig. 8a, importance illumination in Fig. 8b emphasises cells based on the cell volume (voxel count of a cell), which allows user to easily detect volume differences of cells via illumination variations.
title: Fig. 8.
caption: Volume rendering of Cell data set with various illumination approaches: a Conventional illumination, b Importance illumination (volume, w = 0.74), c Distance illumination (volume, w = 0.74), d Perceptual illumination

claim: Figure 8c emphasises cells based on the topological depth, which allows users to percept topological differences of cell structures.
title: Fig. 8.
caption: Volume rendering of Cell data set with various illumination approaches: a Conventional illumination, b Importance illumination (volume, w = 0.74), c Distance illumination (volume, w = 0.74), d Perceptual illumination

claim: Figure 8d enhances the perception differences between cells so that users easily identify different cells.
title: Fig. 8.
caption: Volume rendering of Cell data set with various illumination approaches: a Conventional illumination, b Importance illumination (volume, w = 0.74), c Distance illumination (volume, w = 0.74), d Perceptual illumination

claim: Figure 9 shows the topological attenuation of neghip data set.
title: Fig. 9.
caption:
Topology-aware lighting attenuation of neghip data set: a
V = 229, b
V = 154, c
V = 42

claim: When topological attenuation is applied, we can see from the figure that object lighting is dimmed out with the decrease of lighting speed V from Fig. 9a–c.
title: Fig. 9.
caption:
Topology-aware lighting attenuation of neghip data set: a
V = 229, b
V = 154, c
V = 42

claim: However, different from the conventional lighting attenuation approach which applies same attenuation factor to objects based on distance only, topological attenuation also considers topological features which can be seen from Fig. 9b.
title: Fig. 9.
caption:
Topology-aware lighting attenuation of neghip data set: a
V = 229, b
V = 154, c
V = 42

claim: In Fig. 9b, objects pointed by arrows are not dimmed out as other structures because of their high persistence.
title: Fig. 9.
caption:
Topology-aware lighting attenuation of neghip data set: a
V = 229, b
V = 154, c
V = 42
